column1: ap 10:00|"ten o'clock"|"""Yes
column2: there's a hotel in Innsmouth--called the Gilman House--but I don't believe it can amount to much. I wouldn't advise you to try it. Better stay over here and take the ten o'clock bus tomorrow morning; then you can get an evening bus there for Arkham at eight o'clock. There was a factory inspector who stopped at the Gilman a couple of years ago and he had a lot of unpleasant hints about the place. Seems they get a queer crowd there
column3: for this fellow heard voices in other rooms--though most of 'em was empty--that gave him the shivers. It was foreign talk he thought
column4: but he said the bad thing about it was the kind of voice that sometimes spoke. It sounded so unnatural--slopping like
column5: he said--that he didn't dare undress and go to sleep. Just waited up and lit out the first thing in the morning. The talk went on most all night."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ap < 10:00|"Shortly before ten"|"Shortly before ten the next morning I stood with one small valise in front of Hammond's Drug Store in old Market Square waiting for the Innsmouth bus. As the hour for its arrival drew near I noticed a general drift of the loungers to other places up the street
column2: or to the Ideal Lunch across the square. Evidently the ticket-agent had not exaggerated the dislike which local People bore toward Innsmouth and its denizens. In a few moments a small motor-coach of extreme decrepitude and dirty grey colour rattled down State Street
column3: made a turn
column4: and drew up at the curb beside me. I felt immediately that it was the right one; a guess which the half-illegible sign on the windshield--Arkham-Innsmouth-Newburyport--soon verified."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ap 11:00|eleven|"The sound came from a squat stone church of manifestly later date than most of the houses
column2: built in a clumsy Gothic fashion and having a disproportionately high basement with shuttered windows. Though the hands of its clock were missing on the side I glimpsed
column3: I knew that those hoarse strokes were tolling the hour of eleven. Then suddenly all thoughts of time were blotted out by an onrushing image of sharp intensity and unaccountable horror which had seized me before I knew what it really was. The door of the church basement was open
column4: revealing a rectangle of blackness inside. And as I looked
column5: a certain object crossed or seemed to cross that dark rectangle; burning into my brain a momentary conception of nightmare which was all the more maddening because analysis could not shew a single nightmarish quality in it."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ap 08:00|"eight o'clock"|"Warning me that many of the street signs were down
column2: the youth drew for my benefit a rough but ample and painstaking sketch map of the town's salient features. After a moment's study I felt sure that it would be of great help
column3: and pocketed it with profuse thanks. Disliking the dinginess of the single restaurant I had seen
column4: I bought a fair supply of cheese crackers and ginger wafers to serve as a lunch later on. My program
column6: would be to thread the principal streets
column7: talk with any non-natives I might encounter
column8: and catch the eight o'clock coach for Arkham. The town
column10: formed a significant and exaggerated example of communal decay; but being no sociologist I would limit my serious observations to the field of architecture."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ap 03:00|three|"I shivered as the cracked stroke of three sounded from a belfry on my left. Too well did I recall the squat church from which those notes came. Following Washington Street toward the river
column2: I now faced a new zone of former industry and commerce; noting the ruins of a factory ahead
column3: and seeing others
column4: with the traces of an old railway station and covered railway bridge beyond
column5: up the gorge on my right."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ap 08:00|"eight o'clock"|"About four hours remained for conversation if I were to catch the eight o'clock coach for Arkham
column2: and I began to dole out more liquor to the ancient tippler; meanwhile eating my own frugal lunch. In my donations I was careful not to overshoot the mark
column3: for I did not wish Zadok's vinous garrulousness to pass into a stupor. After an hour his furtive taciturnity shewed signs of disappearing
column4: but much to my disappointment he still sidetracked my questions about Innsmouth and its shadow-haunted past. He would babble of current topics
column5: revealing a wide acquaintance with newspapers and a great tendency to philosophise in a sententious village fashion."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ap 07:15|7:15|"Later I might sift the tale and extract some nucleus of historic allegory; just now I wished to put it out of my head. The hour grown perilously late--my watch said 7:15
column2: and the Arkham bus left Town Square at eight--so I tried to give my thoughts as neutral and practical a cast as possible
column3: meanwhile walking rapidly through the deserted streets of gaping roofs and leaning houses toward the hotel where I had checked my valise and would find my bus."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: 02:00|"2 a.m."|"The place was ghoulish-looking
column2: but I was past minding such impressions and made at once for the staircase revealed by my flashlight--after a hasty glance at my watch
column3: which shewed the hour to be 2 a.m. The steps creaked
column4: but seemed tolerably sound; and I raced down past a barnlike second storey to the ground floor. The desolation was complete
column5: and only echoes answered my footfalls. At length I reached the lower hall at the end of which I saw a faint luminous rectangle marking the ruined Paine Street doorway. Heading the other way
column6: I found the back door also open; and darted out and down five stone steps to the grass-grown cobblestones of the courtyard."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: > 12:00|"past noon"|"It was a gentle daylight rain that awaked me front my stupor in the brush-grown railway cut

column7: and told me that the hour was past noon."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ~ 10:20|"about 10.20 A.M."|"The collapse occurred about 10.20 A.M.
column2: while I was conducting a class in Political Economy VI--history and present tendencies of economics--for juniors and a few sophomores. I began to see strange shapes before my eyes
column3: and to feel that I was in a grotesque room other than the classroom."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: 03:00|"3 A.M."|"At 3 A.M. May 15 my eyes opened and began to speak and my family were thoroughly frightened by the trend of my expression and language. It was clear that I had no remembrance of my identity and my past
column2: though for some reason seemed anxious to conceal his lack of knowledge. My eyes glazed strangely at the persons around me
column3: and the flections of my facial muscles were altogether unfamiliar."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ap 06:00|"6 o'clock"|"It was at 6 o'clock that a hesitant

column3: but no sign of the lean foreigner was ever unearthed."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ~ 18:10|"around 1810"|"Of all the distant objects on Federal Hill
column2: a certain huge
column3: dark church most fascinated Blake. It stood out with especial distinctness at certain hours of the day
column4: and at sunset the great tower and tapering steeple loomed blackly against the flaming sky. It seemed to rest on especially high ground; for the grimy façade
column5: and the obliquely seen north side with sloping roof and the tops of great pointed windows
column6: rose boldly above the tangle of surrounding ridgepoles and chimney-pots. Peculiarly grim and austere
column7: it appeared to be built of stone
column8: stained and weathered with the smoke and storms of a century and more. The style
column9: so far as the glass could show
column10: was that earliest experimental form of Gothic revival which preceded the stately Upjohn period and held over some of the outlines and proportions of the Georgian age. Perhaps it was reared around 1810 or 1815."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: < 00:00|"just before midnight"|"The great storm broke just before midnight on 8 August. Lightning struck repeatedly in all parts of the city
column2: and two remarkable fireballs were reported. The rain was torrential
column3: while a constant fusillade of thunder brought sleeplessness to thousands. Blake was utterly frantic in his fear for the lighting system
column4: and tried to telephone the company around 1 A.M. though by that time service had been temporarily cut off in the interests of safety. He recorded everything in his diary--the large
column7: hieroglyphs telling their own story of growing frenzy and despair
column8: and of entries scrawled blindly in the dark."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column2: but Blake's diary gives no indication of the time. The entry is merely
column3: ""Lights out--God help me."" On Federal Hill there were watchers as anxious as he
column4: and rain-soaked knots of men paraded the square and alleys around the evil church with umbrella-shaded candles
column8: and obscure charms of the many sorts common to southern Italy. They blessed each flash of lightning
column9: and made cryptical signs of fear with their right hands when a turn in the storm caused the flashes to lessen and finally to cease altogether. A rising wind blew out most of the candles
column10: so that the scene grew threatening dark. Someone roused Father Merluzzo of Spirito Santo Church
column11: and he hastened to the dismal square to pronounce whatever helpful syllables he could. Of the restless and curious sounds in the blackened tower
column12: there could be no doubt whatever."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"

column1: ap 02:35|2.35|"For what happened at 2.35 we have the testimony of the priest
column2: a young
column3: intelligent
column4: and well-educated person; of Patrolman William J. Monohan of the Central Station
column5: an officer of the highest reliability who had paused at that part of his beat to inspect the crowd; and of most of the seventy-eight men who had gathered around the church's high back wall--especially those in the square where the eastward façade was visible. Of course there was nothing which can be proved as being outside the order of Nature. The possible causes of such an event are many. No one can speak with certainty of the obscure chemical processes arising in a vast
column8: and long-deserted building of heterogeneous contents. Mephitic vapours--spontaneous combustion--pressure of gases born of long decay--any one of numberless phenomena might be responsible. And then
column10: the factor of conscious charlatanry can by no means be excluded. The thing was really quite simple in itself
column11: and covered less than three minutes of actual time. Father Merluzzo
column13: looked at his watch repeatedly."|"The Haunter of the Dark"|"Howard Phillips Lovecraft"
